overview.summary: The PICA has the most complex, tortuous, and variable course and area of supply of the cerebellar arteries. It arises from the vertebral artery near the inferior olive and passes around the medulla through the cerebellomedullary fissure to supply the inferior half of the fourth ventricular roof, inferior cerebellar peduncle, and suboccipital cerebellar surface. Most PICAs bifurcate into medial and lateral trunks supplying vermis and hemisphere respectively.
key_points: Most complex and variable of cerebellar arteries in course and territory
Intimately related to cerebellomedullary fissure and lower cranial nerves
Forms characteristic caudal and cranial loops around cerebellar tonsil
Supplies tela choroidea, choroid plexus, and majority of suboccipital surface
Origin varies from below foramen magnum to vertebrobasilar junction

slides.title: PICA: Anatomical Overview
slides.key_sentence: PICA is the most complex cerebellar artery
slides.detailed_notes: The posteroinferior cerebellar artery (PICA) has the most complex, tortuous, and variable course and area of supply of all cerebellar arteries. It may be exposed in surgical approaches to the foramen magnum, fourth ventricle, cerebellar hemisphere, brainstem, jugular foramen, cerebellopontine angle, petrous apex, and clivus. The PICA is intimately related to the cerebellomedullary fissure, the inferior half of the ventricular roof, the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and the suboccipital surface. Its area of supply is the most variable of the cerebellar arteries.
slides.surgical_relevance: Central vessel in posterior fossa surgery; encountered in multiple surgical corridors; high anatomical variability requires careful preoperative imaging assessment

slides.title: PICA Segments: Classification System
slides.key_sentence: PICA divided into five segments based on anatomical course
slides.detailed_notes: The PICA is divided into five segments: 1) Anterior medullary - lies anterior to medulla from origin to most prominent part of olive; 2) Lateral medullary - from olive prominence to CN IX/X/XI rootlets; 3) Tonsillomedullary - from CN IX/X/XI rootlets around caudal half of tonsil; 4) Telovelotonsillar - from midlevel of tonsil through fissure between tela/velum and tonsil to exit onto suboccipital surface; 5) Cortical - from fissure exit to terminal cortical branches. These segments are often longer than the distance around medulla or tonsil because PICA frequently has tortuous course forming complex loops on brainstem side among lower cranial nerves, near tonsil, and caudal to fourth ventricle roof. Each segment may include more than one trunk depending on bifurcation level.
slides.surgical_relevance: Segment classification critical for operative planning; predicts PICA location during different surgical approaches; helps communicate intraoperative anatomy
suggested_images: Color-coded diagram showing five PICA segments
Lateral view demonstrating segment boundaries

slides.title: Anterior Medullary Segment
slides.key_sentence: First segment courses anterior to medulla past hypoglossal rootlets
slides.detailed_notes: This segment lies anterior to the medulla, beginning at PICA origin and extending backward past hypoglossal rootlets to the level of a rostrocaudal line through the most prominent part of the inferior olive (marking boundary between anterior and lateral medullary surfaces). Those PICAs arising lateral rather than anterior to medulla do not have an anterior medullary segment. An anterior medullary segment more likely present if PICA arises from superior part of vertebral artery, because vertebral artery courses from lateral side of medulla below to anterior surface above. From origin, PICA usually passes posteriorly around or between hypoglossal rootlets, but occasionally loops upward, downward, laterally, or medially before passing posteriorly around or between CN XII rootlets.
slides.surgical_relevance: Segment at risk during far-lateral approach to foramen magnum; CN XII must be protected during dissection; variable loops may complicate exposure
suggested_images: Anterior view showing PICA coursing around CN XII
Relationship to inferior olive prominence

slides.title: Lateral Medullary Segment
slides.key_sentence: Lateral segment courses from olive to CN IX/X/XI
slides.detailed_notes: This segment begins where the artery passes the most prominent point of the olive and ends at the level of origin of glossopharyngeal, vagus, and accessory rootlets. This segment is present in most PICAs. Its course varies from passing directly posterior to reach the CN IX/X/XI rootlets to ascending, descending, or passing laterally or medially to form one or more complex loops in the cistern on the side of the brainstem before passing between these nerves. The segment is a key landmark for identifying the lower cranial nerves during lateral approaches.
slides.surgical_relevance: Encountered during lateral suboccipital approach; loops may be mistaken for pathology on imaging; manipulation risk to lower cranial nerves
suggested_images: Lateral view of medulla showing PICA course
Complex loop patterns in lateral medullary cistern

slides.title: Tonsillomedullary Segment and Caudal Loop
slides.key_sentence: Tonsillomedullary segment forms caudal loop near tonsil base
slides.detailed_notes: This segment begins where PICA passes posterior to CN IX/X/XI and extends medially across posterior medulla near caudal half of tonsil, ending where artery ascends to midlevel of medial tonsillar surface. Proximal portion usually courses near lateral recess then posteriorly to reach inferior pole of tonsil. Commonly passes medially between lower margin of tonsil and medulla before turning rostrally along medial tonsillar surface. The loop passing near lower tonsil (caudal or infratonsillar loop) has been reported to form caudally convex loop coinciding with caudal pole of tonsil, but may also course superior or inferior to caudal pole without forming loop. In some cases dips below caudal tonsillar margin and even below foramen magnum level. Caudally convex loop not present if PICA passes directly medial between tonsil and medulla, ascends along lateral tonsillar surface, or has low origin with posterior medullary ascent. Caudal limit located 10.0mm inferior to 13.0mm superior (average 1.6mm superior) to caudal tonsil tip; 7.0mm inferior to 18.0mm superior (average 6.9mm superior) to foramen magnum.
slides.surgical_relevance: Caudal loop most at risk during tonsillar resection and suboccipital decompression; loops below foramen magnum require C1 laminectomy for exposure; critical landmark for fourth ventricle approaches
suggested_images: Inferior view showing caudal loop at tonsil base
Variations in caudal loop position relative to foramen magnum

slides.title: Telovelotonsillar Segment and Cranial Loop
slides.key_sentence: Telovelotonsillar segment forms cranial loop near fourth ventricle roof
slides.detailed_notes: This is the most complex segment. It begins at midportion of PICA's ascent along medial tonsillar surface toward fourth ventricle roof and ends where it exits fissures between vermis, tonsil, and hemisphere to reach suboccipital surface. In most (not all) hemispheres, this segment forms a loop with convex rostral curve called the cranial loop. This loop is located caudal to fastigium between cerebellar tonsil below and tela choroidea and posterior medullary velum above. Apex of cranial loop usually overlies central part of inferior medullary velum, but location varies from superior to inferior margin and from medial to lateral extent of velum. Apex of cranial loop inferior to fastigium level in most cases but may extend to fastigium level. This segment gives rise to branches supplying tela choroidea and choroid plexus of fourth ventricle.
slides.surgical_relevance: Cranial loop is critical landmark for telovelotonsillar approach to fourth ventricle; defines safe entry zone; choroidal branches at risk during ventricular access
suggested_images: Sagittal view showing cranial loop between tonsil and velum
Cranial loop apex relationship to fastigium and velum

slides.title: Cortical Segment
slides.key_sentence: Final segment supplies suboccipital cerebellar surface
slides.detailed_notes: This segment begins where trunks and branches leave the groove between vermis medially and tonsil/hemisphere laterally, and includes terminal cortical branches. The bifurcation of PICA often occurs near origin of this segment. Cortical branches radiate outward from superior and lateral borders of tonsil to remainder of vermis and hemisphere. The cortical territory is highly variable, representing the most variable of all cerebellar arteries. The pattern of cortical distribution depends on whether PICA has bifurcated and the relative sizes of medial and lateral trunks.
slides.surgical_relevance: Cortical branches form pial network allowing gentle retraction; extreme variability in territory affects surgical planning and stroke risk assessment
suggested_images: Suboccipital surface showing PICA cortical distribution
Bifurcation into medial and lateral trunks

slides.title: PICA Origin and Vertebral Artery Relationship
slides.key_sentence: PICA originates from vertebral artery with highly variable location
slides.detailed_notes: PICA defined as cerebellar artery arising from vertebral artery. In study of 50 cerebellar hemispheres, all but one had vertebral arteries; 42 of 49 vertebral arteries gave rise to PICAs (84%). Both vertebral artery and associated PICA absent in a few hemispheres. PICA rarely absent bilaterally but may arise as double or duplicate PICA. If present, PICA is largest vertebral artery branch. Vertebral artery sometimes terminates in PICA. 41 of 42 PICAs arose as single trunk, 1 as duplicate trunk. Origin site varies from below foramen magnum to vertebrobasilar junction: 35 of 42 PICAs arose above foramen magnum level, 7 originated below (few extradural). Origin located 14.0mm below to 26.0mm above foramen magnum (average 8.6mm above); 0 to 35.0mm (average 16.9mm) below vertebrobasilar junction. PICA arises from posterior or lateral vertebral artery surfaces more often than medial or anterior surfaces. Initial course most commonly posterior, lateral, or superior rather than anterior, medial, or inferior.
slides.surgical_relevance: Low-origin PICAs (below foramen magnum) require C1 laminectomy for proximal control; high origin affects far-lateral approach planning; extradural origin rare but critical to recognize
suggested_images: Diagram showing range of PICA origin levels
Circumferential origin distribution on vertebral artery

slides.title: PICA Diameter and Hypoplasia
slides.key_sentence: PICA diameter highly variable with 5-16% hypoplastic
slides.detailed_notes: Vertebral artery diameter greater at dural entrance (range 1.8-6.2mm, average 4.4mm) than at PICA origin (range 1.6-5.7mm, average 3.9mm) or termination (range 1.7-5.5mm, average 3.7mm). PICA diameter at origin ranges from 0.5 to 3.4mm (average 2.0mm). Origin was 1.0mm or less in diameter in 4 cerebellae. PICA reported hypoplastic in 5-16% of cerebellar hemispheres. This substantial size variability has important implications for collateral circulation and compensatory enlargement of other cerebellar arteries, particularly AICA.
slides.surgical_relevance: Hypoplastic PICA may be difficult to identify on imaging; associated with enlarged AICA supplying traditional PICA territory; affects aneurysm clip selection and anastomosis feasibility
suggested_images: Comparison of normal vs hypoplastic PICA

slides.title: PICA Bifurcation Patterns
slides.key_sentence: PICA bifurcates into medial and lateral trunks
slides.detailed_notes: Most PICAs bifurcate into smaller medial and larger lateral trunk; trunk before bifurcation is main trunk. Medial trunk supplies vermis and adjacent hemisphere; lateral trunk supplies most of hemispheric and tonsillar parts of suboccipital surface. PICAs not bifurcating are usually small and supply only small area on tonsil and adjacent vermis/hemisphere. Bifurcation usually occurs posterior to brainstem as PICA courses around tonsil. Most common bifurcation site is in telovelotonsillar fissure as artery courses around rostral tonsil pole. Bifurcation location relative to tonsil creates four patterns: inferolateral, inferomedial, superomedial, and superolateral, each affecting subsequent trunk courses and distributions. Lateral trunk divides into larger hemispheric trunk (multiple branches to hemisphere) and smaller tonsillar branches (posterior and inferior tonsil surfaces), most commonly near posterior margin of medial tonsillar surface.
slides.surgical_relevance: Bifurcation pattern affects surgical exposure; early bifurcation creates more vessels at risk in telovelotonsillar approach; understanding patterns helps predict vascular anatomy during dissection
suggested_images: Diagram showing four bifurcation patterns
Medial and lateral trunk territories on cerebellum

slides.title: PICA Perforating Arteries
slides.key_sentence: Perforating branches supply medulla from all three medullary segments
slides.detailed_notes: Perforating arteries are small arteries arising from three medullary segments terminating in brainstem. Divided into direct (straight course to brainstem) and circumflex types. Circumflex type passes around brainstem before terminating; divided into short (<90° circumference) and long (>90°) types, both sending branches along course. Perforators have numerous branches and anastomoses creating plexiform pattern on medullary surface. Anterior medullary segments give rise to 0-2 (average 1.0) per hemisphere, most commonly short circumflex posterior type supplying anterior, lateral, or posterior medulla. Lateral medullary segments: 0-5 (average 1.8) branches per hemisphere supplying lateral or posterior medulla, predominantly short circumflex. Tonsillomedullary segment: most perforators of any segment (range 0-11 per hemisphere, average 3.3), either direct or short circumflex with former predominating, terminating in lateral and posterior medulla.
slides.surgical_relevance: Perforators most numerous from tonsillomedullary segment; careful preservation required to prevent lateral medullary infarction (Wallenberg syndrome); plexiform anastomoses provide some collateral protection
suggested_images: Perforating arteries entering medulla from PICA segments
Circumflex perforator course around medulla

slides.title: Vertebral Artery Perforators
slides.key_sentence: Vertebral artery perforators overlap with PICA branches
slides.detailed_notes: Perforating branches of PICA intermingle and overlap with those arising from vertebral artery. Vertebral artery segment distal to PICA origin more frequently gives rise to perforators than segment proximal to PICA origin. Perforating branches arising between vertebral artery dural entrance and PICA origin most commonly short circumflex or direct type terminating predominantly on lateral medulla. Those arising between PICA origin and vertebrobasilar junction predominantly short circumflex type terminating on anterior and lateral medullary surfaces. Vertebral artery segment distal to PICA origin also gives rise to a few branches entering choroid plexus protruding from foramen of Luschka. This overlap creates redundancy but also complexity in predicting infarction patterns.
slides.surgical_relevance: Vertebral artery perforators at risk during PICA aneurysm clipping and vertebral artery sacrifice; distal vertebral segment particularly important for medullary perfusion
suggested_images: Medullary surface showing PICA and vertebral perforators
Distribution of perforators from proximal vs distal vertebral segments

slides.title: PICA Choroidal Arteries
slides.key_sentence: PICA supplies tela choroidea and fourth ventricle choroid plexus
slides.detailed_notes: PICA gives rise to branches supplying tela choroidea and choroid plexus of fourth ventricle, usually supplying choroid plexus near midline of ventricular roof and in medial part of lateral recess. This includes all of medial segment and adjacent part of lateral segment of choroid plexus. More choroidal branches arise from tonsillomedullary and telovelotonsillar segments than from lateral or anterior medullary segment. AICA usually supplies the portion of choroid plexus not supplied by PICA, commonly that part in cerebellopontine angle and adjacent part of lateral recess. This complementary distribution between PICA and AICA ensures complete plexus vascularization.
slides.surgical_relevance: Choroidal branches at risk during telovelotonsillar approach; injury may cause choroid plexus ischemia and CSF production changes; preservation important for ventricular roof integrity
suggested_images: Choroidal branches entering fourth ventricle roof

slides.title: PICA Cortical Arteries: Territory Overview
slides.key_sentence: PICA supplies majority of ipsilateral suboccipital cerebellar surface
slides.detailed_notes: Most constant area supplied by PICA includes majority of ipsilateral half of suboccipital cerebellar surface, including majority of suboccipital surface of ipsilateral hemisphere and tonsil, ipsilateral half of vermis, and anterior aspect of tonsil. Largest area supplied by PICA includes all ipsilateral half of suboccipital surface with overlap onto contralateral half and adjacent parts of tentorial and petrosal surfaces. Smallest area supplied confined to inferior part of ipsilateral cerebellar tonsil. Cortical area supplied by PICA more variable than AICA and SCA. If PICA absent on one side, contralateral PICA or ipsilateral AICA supplies most of area normally supplied by absent PICA. This extreme variability reflects the reciprocal relationship between cerebellar arteries.
slides.surgical_relevance: Variable territory complicates stroke prediction with PICA sacrifice; preoperative angiography essential to assess contralateral PICA and ipsilateral AICA size; absent PICA creates different vascular anatomy
suggested_images: Typical PICA territory on suboccipital surface

slides.title: PICA Cortical Branches: Classification
slides.key_sentence: Cortical branches divided into vermian, hemispheric, and tonsillar groups
slides.detailed_notes: Cortical branches divided into hemispheric, vermian, and tonsillar groups. Vermian branches usually arise from medial trunk; hemispheric and tonsillar branches from lateral trunk. Each half of vermis divided into median and paramedian segments. Hemisphere lateral to vermis divided into medial, intermediate, and lateral segments. There is reciprocal relationship with frequent overlap in areas supplied by tonsillar, hemispheric, and vermian branches. Trunks passing through tonsillomedullary fissure send branches to medulla, and trunks passing through telovelotonsillar fissure send ascending branches to dentate nucleus. This segmental organization allows systematic description of territory but individual variation is substantial.
slides.surgical_relevance: Branch classification helps communicate intraoperative findings; vermian branches critical for midline cerebellar function; tonsillar branches at risk during tonsillar resection
suggested_images: Color-coded diagram of cortical branch territories

slides.title: Extradural PICA Origin
slides.key_sentence: PICA rarely originates extradurally below foramen magnum
slides.detailed_notes: A few PICAs arising below foramen magnum may arise from vertebral artery in extradural location as vertebral arteries course behind atlantooccipital joints. In these cases, PICAs enter dura at level of dorsolateral medulla and do not have an anterior medullary or full lateral medullary segment. PICA may give off posterior meningeal artery, penetrate dura by passing through dural cuff around vertebral artery, and loop downward behind accessory nerve and C1-C2 roots before ascending to enter cerebellomedullary fissure. PICA penetrates dural cuff with vertebral artery and C1 nerve root. Accessory nerve passes posterior to both vertebral artery and PICA. Rostral attachment of dentate ligament may ascend between PICA and vertebral artery to attach to dura at foramen magnum level. Small posterior spinal artery may arise from PICA and course along dorsolateral spinal cord.
anatomical_concepts: C1 nerve root and accessory nerve anatomy
slides.surgical_relevance: Extradural PICA origin requires different surgical approach; at risk during far-lateral or extreme lateral transcondylar approaches; dentate ligament division may expose PICA; posterior meningeal branches may cause confusion during exposure
suggested_images: Extradural PICA origin behind atlantooccipital joint

slides.title: Loops and Fourth Ventricle Access
slides.key_sentence: Caudal and cranial loops are critical surgical landmarks
slides.detailed_notes: PICA forms two characteristic loops: caudal loop at lower tonsil pole (tonsillomedullary segment) and cranial loop near upper tonsil pole (telovelotonsillar segment). Caudal loop location varies 10.0mm inferior to 13.0mm superior to caudal tonsil tip (average 1.6mm superior) and 7.0mm inferior to 18.0mm superior to foramen magnum (average 6.9mm superior). Cranial loop apex usually overlies central inferior medullary velum but varies from superior to inferior margin and medial to lateral extent of velum; usually inferior to fastigium but may reach fastigium level. Loops may be formed by main trunk, medial trunk, or lateral trunk depending on bifurcation location. Understanding loop anatomy is fundamental to safe fourth ventricle access via telovelotonsillar approach.
slides.surgical_relevance: Loops define safe entry zone for telovelotonsillar approach to fourth ventricle; cranial loop is key landmark; loops below foramen magnum require extended exposure; identification prevents inadvertent vessel injury
suggested_images: Sagittal view showing both caudal and cranial loops

slides.title: PICA Absence and Duplication
slides.key_sentence: PICA absent in 16% of hemispheres, rarely duplicated
slides.detailed_notes: In study of 50 cerebellar hemispheres: 42 (84%) had PICA, 8 (16%) did not. Both vertebral artery and PICA absent in a few hemispheres. PICA rarely absent bilaterally. When PICA arises, 41 of 42 arose as single trunk, only 1 as duplicate trunk. When PICA absent, contralateral PICA or ipsilateral AICA supplies area normally supplied by absent PICA through enlarged anastomotic channels. Duplicate PICAs (when present) termed rostral and caudal duplicate PICAs with territories similar to medial and lateral trunks of bifurcated single PICA. Rostral duplicate PICA may loop upward into cerebellopontine angle mimicking AICA.
anatomical_concepts: Compensatory AICA or contralateral PICA enlargement
slides.surgical_relevance: PICA absence must be recognized preoperatively; creates different surgical anatomy with enlarged AICA or contralateral PICA; duplicate PICA increases vessels at risk; rostral duplicate may be confused with AICA
suggested_images: Absent PICA with enlarged contralateral PICA

slides.title: PICA and Lower Cranial Nerves
slides.key_sentence: PICA intimately related to CN IX, X, XI, XII throughout course
slides.detailed_notes: Anterior medullary segment passes around or between hypoglossal (CN XII) rootlets. Lateral medullary segment extends from olive prominence to glossopharyngeal, vagus, and accessory (CN IX/X/XI) rootlets, often forming loops among these nerves. Tonsillomedullary segment begins where PICA passes posterior to CN IX/X/XI. These nerves are frequently stretched around PICA loops, particularly when vessel is tortuous or forms prominent caudal loop. Perforating branches supply brainstem entry zones of these nerves. Close anatomical relationship explains how PICA pathology (aneurysm, dolichoectasia, arteriovenous malformation) can cause lower cranial nerve dysfunction.
anatomical_concepts: Sequential CN XII then CN IX/X/XI relationships
Nerve rootlets stretched around PICA loops
slides.surgical_relevance: Lower cranial nerves must be identified and protected during PICA dissection; nerves stretched around loops require careful untethering; PICA manipulation may cause transient or permanent cranial neuropathies
suggested_images: PICA course through lower cranial nerves

slides.title: Surgical Approaches and PICA Exposure
slides.key_sentence: Multiple approaches access different PICA segments and pathology
slides.detailed_notes: PICA may be exposed in surgical approaches to foramen magnum, fourth ventricle, cerebellar hemisphere, brainstem, jugular foramen, cerebellopontine angle, petrous apex, and clivus. Midline suboccipital approach: excellent for viewing PICA cortical branches and accessing cranial loop via telovelotonsillar approach to fourth ventricle. Lateral suboccipital (retrosigmoid): exposes lateral medullary, tonsillomedullary, and telovelotonsillar segments; useful for PICA aneurysms and cerebellopontine angle pathology. Far-lateral/extreme lateral approach: provides access to anterior and lateral medullary segments, vertebral artery-PICA junction, and foramen magnum region; may require C1 laminectomy for low-origin PICAs and condylar drilling for ventral access. Telovelotonsillar approach: splits tonsils to access fourth ventricle between cranial loops with minimal cerebellar retraction; preserves PICA cortical branches.
slides.surgical_relevance: Approach selection based on pathology location and PICA segment involved; low origin may require extended foramen magnum exposure; telovelotonsillar approach preserves PICA while accessing ventricle; understanding PICA's complex course essential for safe surgery in any approach
